context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: I can go in to that now, Your Honor, if you wish.
You can come to that later.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: I was going to come to it later.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Before -- before you move on, why is that the cases put by Justice Black that the Lower Basin (Inaudible) just that amount no matter what in perpetuity?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Why if you were not brought in or sought to be brought in by either parties that you should be rushing in, hence, you wouldn't be bound by the (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: Well, but that's too dangerous to our rights.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You say you don't -- you don't want them to speak their motion to find these of altruism into your intrabasin affair.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Justice Harlan, the thrust of his question is that this litigation couldn't -- there have been intrabasin concerned, as far as it's involved in the interplay of any between the basin therefore intrabasin.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: Well, now, we -- we don't believe in this case.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: There are any interbasin questions.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: I can go in to that now, Your Honor, if you wish.
You can come to that later.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: I was going to come to it later.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Before -- before you move on, why is that the cases put by Justice Black that the Lower Basin (Inaudible) just that amount no matter what in perpetuity?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Why if you were not brought in or sought to be brought in by either parties that you should be rushing in, hence, you wouldn't be bound by the (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: Well, but that's too dangerous to our rights.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You say you don't -- you don't want them to speak their motion to find these of altruism into your intrabasin affair.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Justice Harlan, the thrust of his question is that this litigation couldn't -- there have been intrabasin concerned, as far as it's involved in the interplay of any between the basin therefore intrabasin.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: Well, now, we -- we don't believe in this case.

context.speaker: Hatfield Chilson
context.text: There are any interbasin questions.

context.speaker: Robert N. Gorman
context.text: That's my opinion.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Robert N. Gorman
context.text: That's my opinion.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And so we go on merely to the question of Justice Harlan has initiated.

context.speaker: Robert N. Gorman
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Exactly, what it is that the Florida court decreed to which Ohio if it has jurisdiction, which Ohio must make obedient?

Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Company of Amer.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Company of Amer.case_name: Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Company of America, Inc.
Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Company of Amer.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 05, 1955 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Sherman Minton
context.text: Why shouldn't Vermont apply the -- enforce the New York law set out in the contracts unless that law is suspended or is the public policies of their own states?

context.speaker: Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
context.text: Well, I don't think this is a matter of -- of full faith and credit.

context.speaker: Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
context.text: The -- the Shafer case, which is the only case we found directly on it, held that a provision on a contract that the law of New York, and it did involve the New York Arbitration Act, would apply, had no more weight than if the people involved in the contract had provided that this arbitration agreement shall be irrevocable and enforceable.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I as you why you don't shortly or briefly answer Justice Minton's question by saying it is offensive to Vermont?

context.speaker: Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: As I understand it that's the policy of Vermont, isn't it?

Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Company of Amer.speaker: Justice Reed
Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Company of Amer.case_name: Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Company of America, Inc.
Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Company of Amer.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 05, 1955 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That's a policy of -- of protecting rights as utilized in courts and so on.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Is there any policy to the contrary in Vermont?

context.speaker: Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Well, as I understand what your answer to Justice Frankfurter, Vermont would be able to say no agreement of another State would be enforced in Vermont.

context.speaker: Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
context.text: Would say what, Your Honor?

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: No agreements made in another State would be enforced in Vermont.

Cold Metal Process Company v. United Eng.speaker: Justice Black
Cold Metal Process Company v. United Eng.case_name: Cold Metal Process Company v. United Engineering & Foundry Company
Cold Metal Process Company v. United Eng.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 28, 1956 (PART 2)

context.speaker: William H. Webb
context.text: Because it is not a final decision as that term is understood in the law.

context.speaker: William H. Webb
context.text: And of course, finality is a congressional requirement insofar as appealability is concern except in those few instances covered by Section 1292.

context.speaker: William H. Webb
context.text: There is --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I assume that the -- in answer to my question mean would explain your answer to Justice Frankfurter in the beginning.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: And here, according to you, you have a case where under 1291 could not possibly be taken up because it's splitting up at two courses that acted as one.

context.speaker: William H. Webb
context.text: Exactly, Your Honor.

context.speaker: David I. Shapiro
context.text: That's right, sir.

context.speaker: David I. Shapiro
context.text: That's our position.

context.speaker: David I. Shapiro
context.text: That's what we think the basic issue is.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Shapiro, let's see if I am -- if I am correct in assuming -- am I correct in assuming, to understand this, that the only documentation before us on the basis of which his employment was terminated was a letter giving these five charges that had been written a while ago in answer to Justice Harlan.

context.speaker: David I. Shapiro
context.text: That's correct, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: His reply on paper refusing to answer the inquiry terminated, and the termination letter from the President to say, on the basis of that, those charges and other documents, not disclosed, will all turn into the Government's second hand.

context.speaker: John F. Franks
context.text: Seemingly, Mr. Justice Minton, yes, in this case.

context.speaker: John F. Franks
context.text: Now, that is, of course, one of the arguments between counsel here where we draw some fine lines.

context.speaker: John F. Franks
context.text: I have referred to the statement of the Court where they talk about duplicate coverage in some point.

context.speaker: Sherman Minton
context.text: Well, if that's -- if that's true, then this argument about, as suggested by Justice Frankfurter might -- as the Commerce might fall out as a mere surplusage.

context.speaker: John F. Franks
context.text: Well, that could possibly be, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John F. Franks
context.text: I see that it might.

Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Sout.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 24, 1956

context.speaker: Hilbert P. Zarky
context.text: The thought may well have been that Kirby and Burton-Sutton spoke for themselves and that exactly where the line should be drawn was not too clear, but --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Well, which part of this regulation do you consider is out by reason of Kirby and Sutton?

context.speaker: Hilbert P. Zarky
context.text: Well, to the extent that the regulations make the flat blunt statement.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: The part that Justice Reed read?

context.speaker: Hilbert P. Zarky
context.text: This part here, “Thus, an agreement between the owner of an economic interest --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: In the brief, where is that on?

context.speaker: Simon E. Sobeloff

context.speaker: Simon E. Sobeloff
context.text: I think it is.

context.speaker: Simon E. Sobeloff
context.text: I think it's precisely their the same thing.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I feel I have held their view in Justice Black's (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Simon E. Sobeloff

context.speaker: Simon E. Sobeloff

Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Com.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Com.case_name: Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Company v. Union Pacific Railroad Company
Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Com.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 24, 1956

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Are you saying (Voice Overlap) --if they only have a through route, he must still may, must he not, the originating carrier issue a through bill of lading?

context.speaker: Robert W. Ginnane
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Robert W. Ginnane
context.text: And if there are alternative through routes then section 15 (8), it gives the shipper the right to specify which of the alternative through routes to be employed.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Ginnane, may I revert to Justice Reed's earlier question?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: In the course of your reply you said that the Commission was divided 5-to-5.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, let me clear up in my mind.

Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Com.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Com.case_name: Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Company v. Union Pacific Railroad Company
Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Com.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 24, 1956

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: What's the duty of the Court in connection with deciding those facts anew or as to deciding those facts for the first time?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: What is your idea of the function of the Court there as of -- in reviewing that?

context.speaker: Robert W. Ginnane
context.text: That in the circumstances of this case since the burden of proof or persuasion was upon Rio Grande, the Commission's report, full report concurred in by five members of the Commission in finding -- in -- in which it was found that through routes did not exist, that that should be treated as the order of the -- of the Commission which was open to challenge in the courts.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The reason I raise the question is because in your answer to Justice Harlan yesterday when he asked you what the question was or what you represented the position of the Commission, you said was commendable candor or appropriate candor -- candor appropriate on the part of (Inaudible) They probably get credit for.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But that's so difficult to perhaps, a doubtful question on which you cared for, take a dogmatic position.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I take it that the Commission is here taking a dogmatic position.

Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Com.speaker: Justice Warren
Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Com.case_name: Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Company v. Union Pacific Railroad Company
Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Com.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 24, 1956

context.speaker: Robert W. Ginnane
context.text: I can't find it now, Your Honor, I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Robert W. Ginnane
context.text: But in -- but in effect, it provided that a carrier may cancel existing through routes and joint rates and subject to veto by the Commission.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Perhaps, you would give us --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Justice Reed would like a little memorandum on that subject, would you supply to us please?

context.speaker: Robert W. Ginnane
context.text: It's very -- be very glad to.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: And to counsel of course.

Dixie Carriers, Inc. v. United States.speaker: Justice Reed
Dixie Carriers, Inc. v. United States.case_name: Dixie Carriers, Inc. v. United States
Dixie Carriers, Inc. v. United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 27, 1956 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Nuel D. Belnap
context.text: They can go to the Commission, yes, sir.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Well, when you made your effort to get, what you call, the combination rate with water and rail?

context.speaker: Nuel D. Belnap
context.text: We now have a combination rate.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Well, when -- when you went to -- to object to that, I noticed on your roman II that there's question mark after the 2.95 which I understand to your answer to Justice Frankfurter.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Now, why -- why couldn't you find out what that was when you were there?

context.speaker: Nuel D. Belnap
context.text: That is not a published rate.

Dixie Carriers, Inc. v. United States.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Dixie Carriers, Inc. v. United States.case_name: Dixie Carriers, Inc. v. United States
Dixie Carriers, Inc. v. United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 27, 1956 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Well, it could do that, doesn't it?

context.speaker: Samuel R. Howell
context.text: Well, it did in -- in effect here.

context.speaker: Samuel R. Howell
context.text: It passed on the reason it found that there was a -- that the barge lines were making a -- a gross profit after -- they're making a profit of $1 a ton, for every ton of sulphur they move from Galveston to East St. Louis, and that the rail -- the rail rates from -- of the railroads was depressed, and the --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Howell, does the record --does the record show -- I haven't read it, does the record give any light on the question put by Mr. Justice Black, namely, has there been a diminution in barge traffic --

context.speaker: Samuel R. Howell
context.text: The reason of the rate --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I mean, at large, I mean, with reference to this commodity, is this -- is this case based on the fact that this operates -- shows the barges can't do business or business profit?

East Texas Motor Freight Lines, Inc. v..speaker: Justice Frankfurter
East Texas Motor Freight Lines, Inc. v..case_name: East Texas Motor Freight Lines, Inc. v. Frozen Food Express
East Texas Motor Freight Lines, Inc. v..title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 07, 1956

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Robert W. Ginnane
context.text: The Commission contends that dressed poultry and it relies partly on the analogy to dressed meat, that dressed poultry is not an exempt agricultural commodity.

context.speaker: Robert W. Ginnane
context.text: The court below held that it was.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Ginnane, you've already qualified for me at least, your remark that the Commission can get nothing or that one gets nothing out of the statute, because the colloquy as it develops between you and Mr. Justice Reed show that one does get something.

context.speaker: Robert W. Ginnane
context.text: I stand corrected sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If a statute, if he didn't use the word agricultural commodities and livestock then I'm certainly entitled to call some entry that livestock was not included in agriculture commodity (Inaudible) inference to include this livestock in agricultural commodity.

General Box Company v. United States.speaker: Justice Clark
General Box Company v. United States.case_name: General Box Company v. United States
General Box Company v. United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 1956

context.speaker: S. Billingsley Hill
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: So, what I was wondering about was whether or not the question of their recovery against the Levee Board within their (Inaudible) at all so they never sued the Levee Board.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Somewhere, I think Justice Black asked you whether or not that question will still be here when we get to see the fact depending on whether or not the Box Company might sue the Levee Board.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Well, that question run in the case so then -- they were made then a party, didn't they?

context.speaker: S. Billingsley Hill
context.text: The -- the Box Company did not, no.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That's what I assume, is in fact the decision.

context.speaker: A. Alan Reich
context.text: Of course, it was the decision.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Oh, yes.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Justice Black --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I'd like to ask you --

context.speaker: A. Alan Reich
context.text: Yes, sir.

Gibson v. Lockheed Aircraft Service, Inc.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Gibson v. Lockheed Aircraft Service, Inc.case_name: Gibson v. Lockheed Aircraft Service, Inc.
Gibson v. Lockheed Aircraft Service, Inc.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 06, 1955

context.speaker: Emory A. Cantey
context.text: -- that goes to my whole argument, Mr. Justice Black.

context.speaker: Emory A. Cantey
context.text: If you are going to construe this rule rigidly and inflexibly, it does not.

context.speaker: Emory A. Cantey
context.text: If you're going to construe this rule in accordance with its intent and purpose, it most certainly does, because its intent and purpose is, that there won't be errors assigned that were timely called to the attention of the trial judge.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Cantey, it's not without interest, at least to me, historically, that the phrases that because they're often, they're policies of Justice Black to tell you, state your fixed, it doesn't matter before this is as I gather from reading Mr. Justice Stone's opinion in U.S against Atkinsons 451 to be in existence that is that it's indicated, you lay down the general rule with all of high points before that time, I believe goes on to say, namely, perhaps to have -- they must be held it's within the duty of the judge to put the issue with the jury.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And then he goes on to say, it is substantial to that adopted by Rule 10, something that is one of the rules in the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit --

context.speaker: Emory A. Cantey
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What was it --

context.speaker: A.L. Wirin
context.text: I -- I'm sure I can't be certain as to -- as to what was in his mind but I -- but I think I know.

context.speaker: A.L. Wirin
context.text: One of the --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If there are because maybe there are, was made there on the arguments that on the question put to you by Mr. Justice Harlan.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Is there some standard, some issues, some -- what we call a -- a question of criterion or a criterion rather thatn questions of credibility was involved.

context.speaker: A.L. Wirin
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Simon E. Sobeloff
context.text: And the question that you got to decide here is, does this go too far.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: What?

context.speaker: Simon E. Sobeloff
context.text: Does this go too far?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Is -- is it that that of the question that Justice Frankfurter suggested that you have a man, that the Government has the right to try him for violation of federal statutes.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: He is insane and dangerous.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: The Government has him there and has the right to hold him to -- to have trial and the findings are that -- not that he will never get all right, but that for sometime, not known, he -- the Government had him on his hands.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Is that right?

context.speaker: Norman M. Littell
context.text: They did indeed, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Norman M. Littell
context.text: Well, briefly on the issues, my time is running hard --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What do you say to Justice Reed's suggestion that this gets down to -- if you -- if you mind your own analysis, (Inaudible) the state law?

context.speaker: Norman M. Littell
context.text: Your Honor, I think it was the most deliberate mistake that was ever made.

context.speaker: Norman M. Littell
context.text: The other law is completely unsatisfactory for their purposes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Marquis, the finding that certain brands were recorded is about as rudimentary and elementary and simple and unambiguous to the finding of fact that one can conceive.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And therefore, the general objection to the inferences drawn, I should hardly think would cover such a finding that in a certain place, there's a piece of paper or books in which (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Roger P. Marquis
context.text: I -- of course there, we have the fact that it runs all through this case because the testimony was they looked in the book and it wasn't there.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, I'm not saying you shouldn't have challenged it, I'm suggesting that your answer to Justice Minton's question, you attack the structure of the conclusive report was hardly the type of question of an entry in a book.

context.speaker: Roger P. Marquis
context.text: Well, perhaps, our statement of points on appeal was not detailed enough.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, that doesn't mean by not certainly defined is --

context.speaker: William B. Murrish
context.text: The right to have counsel includes the right to consult and all of these maybe strictly criminal trial rights originally.

context.speaker: William B. Murrish
context.text: And it is not upon any of those in which I lay reliance, but rather upon the requirement of federal due process which will not permit a state to change its state constitutional provisions to the extent of violating the secured right of an accused to be present at the substantive portions of his trial.

context.speaker: William B. Murrish
context.text: And it's that due process security of fair hearing rather than any strictly criminal one only upon which I rely.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I ask Mr. Justice Harlan's question?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Do I understand you to say that he did say, “We have to lay down the general rule such as this Court laid down in Johnson, observed proper aid of counsel in all for this, not that intricate (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Do I understand you, permit this Court in this case, the proposition that he must lay down as a general rule of general applicability in all deportation cases that a potential deportee must be personally be present at the time that any -- and the depositions are as -- as a legal mode of procedure to rule out, is that your position or are you talking about

Indian Towing Company, Inc. v. United St.speaker: Justice Warren
Indian Towing Company, Inc. v. United St.case_name: Indian Towing Company, Inc. v. United States
Indian Towing Company, Inc. v. United St.title: ORAL REARGUMENT - OCTOBER 13, 1955

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: What is the essential difference?

context.speaker: Lester S. Jayson
context.text: The difference is that the railroad has itself created a danger or hazard.

context.speaker: Lester S. Jayson
context.text: And therefore, anyone, anyone who creates a hazard -- hazard duty at common law in a recognized duty to warn others, but no one has the duty to go out on a publicly travelled duty and stand there and warn the public of something that he didn't himself create.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, that's in -- then, that go to the -- the observation of Mr. or Justice Frankfurter to the effect that this Act says, “Not actions that are the same but those that are alike.”

context.speaker: Lester S. Jayson
context.text: But no one, other than the Government, undertakes these obligations for the community at large.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You say nobody, but a Government.

International Harvester Credit Corporati.speaker: Justice Warren
International Harvester Credit Corporati.case_name: International Harvester Credit Corporation v. Goodrich
International Harvester Credit Corporati.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 17, 1956

context.speaker: John Lord O'Brian
context.text: And I'm not contesting that although --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But suppose the State said that it would -- it would come before the priority of the tax lien would come before the -- the seller's mortgage rights, what then?

context.speaker: John Lord O'Brian
context.text: Well, I haven't given any thought to tell the truth to -- the right of anybody but of conditional vendor here.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, you said a few moments ago in answer to Justice Burton as I recall that -- that there was a difference between the two.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now, between --

context.speaker: John Lord O'Brian
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John V. Lindsay
context.text: And that is that if it appears affirmatively to be so capricious, so that the Attorney General says that -- that he will grant suspension for this man because he's got red hair and not for this man because he doesn't --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, then (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: John V. Lindsay
context.text: -- of course that is reviewable.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- question arises whether -- and the question arises whether in construing a regulation by him, I take it that's what Justice Harlan means by administrative proceedings.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: In construing the regulation by him which he saw fit to formulate, to set up isn't conflict -- asking on confidential information.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Doesn't that have such likely a rule that's caprice in conduct and what you know to be the variant and capricious nature of confidential information?

context.speaker: Carl H. Imlay
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Carl H. Imlay
context.text: The interest --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Imlay, may I ask just one more question on the line of Justice Frankfurter's questions.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Am I correct in understanding that in no case has there been a prosecution for such as this, such as these cases in the place where the local board gave the order?

context.speaker: Carl H. Imlay
context.text: I -- I know of none, Mr. Chief Justice, if --

Liquid Carbonic Corp. v. United States.case_name: Liquid Carbonic Corp. v. United States

context.text: Never mind now.

context.speaker: James F. Dwyer
context.text: I'm -- I'm sorry, Mr. Justice Harlan.

context.speaker: James F. Dwyer
context.text: I can't pick it out readily in this record.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Perhaps you could send a memorandum to -- to Mr. Justice Harlan if you will consider.

context.speaker: James F. Dwyer
context.text: I'll be -- all right, I would be happy to do that.

Mastro Plastics Corporation v. National.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Mastro Plastics Corporation v. National.case_name: Mastro Plastics Corporation v. National Labor Relations Board
Mastro Plastics Corporation v. National.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 17, 1955

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Congress itself, as I say, made the determination and said, “We will put it in the statute, any employee who engages in a strike of this kind that we've described in Section 8 (d), we think, is so serious that you should be automatically disqualified,” and --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Namely, for economic purposes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: For purposes of Sections 8, 9, and 10 insofar as his right to vote is concerned, insofar as his right to reinstatement may be involved, and insofar as he may ask for relief from the Board.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I suggest it doesn't take very -- take me very far from reaching the questions put to you by Mr. Justice Harlan that Congress may also have changed the wording but you know even better than I it's not always an easy question as to where the gravamen, whether this was an economic strike or was it an unfair labor practice strike.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Those are not easy mathematical questions.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Nobody knows better than you.

Michel v. Louisiana.speaker: Justice Reed
Michel v. Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 2: MICHEL V. LOUISIANA (32) - NOVEMBER 09, 1955

context.speaker: Leon D. Hubert, Jr.
context.text: We disagree with the Supreme Court of Louisiana which addressed itself precisely to the question.

context.speaker: Leon D. Hubert, Jr.
context.text: Parenthetically, I have called that, not as on March 5th as the counsel contend.

context.speaker: Leon D. Hubert, Jr.
context.text: Louisiana addressed itself directly to that point and filed to the contrary.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: I heard your reply to Mr. Justice Black in -- in reference to the minute entry on March the 3rd that that -- as I understand from you that you think that is subject to attack as not being correct?

context.speaker: Leon D. Hubert, Jr.
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: Leon D. Hubert, Jr.
context.text: You mean that minute entry itself is inaccurate?

Michel v. Louisiana.speaker: Justice Black
Michel v. Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 2: MICHEL V. LOUISIANA (32) - NOVEMBER 09, 1955

context.speaker: Leon D. Hubert, Jr.
context.text: A simple statement practically formed could be done in a half an hour.

context.speaker: Leon D. Hubert, Jr.
context.text: The State therefore submits, if this Court pleases, that --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Of course, we didn't hold in the Avery case that a rigid law to that effect would have complied with due process.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: It -- it was in the nature of examining the circumstances such as Mr. Justice Frankfurter mentioned a while ago in connection to this case.

context.speaker: Leon D. Hubert, Jr.
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: How it was applied.

Michel v. Louisiana.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Michel v. Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 1: PORET V. LOUISIANA (36) - NOVEMBER 09, 1955

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: They waited for the other codefendant.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You don't have to try codefendants together.

context.speaker: Felicien Y. Lozes
context.text: Nothing was done by anyone as I stated in my --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But then Justice Harlan's question becomes relevant.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Then Justice Harlan's question becomes relevant.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: How do you know that counsel may not have thought instead of that pleading on trial?

Michel v. Louisiana.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Michel v. Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 1: PORET V. LOUISIANA (36) - NOVEMBER 09, 1955

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You don't have to try codefendants together.

context.speaker: Felicien Y. Lozes
context.text: Nothing was done by anyone as I stated in my --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But then Justice Harlan's question becomes relevant.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Then Justice Harlan's question becomes relevant.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: How do you know that counsel may not have thought instead of that pleading on trial?

context.speaker: Felicien Y. Lozes
context.text: I submit Your Honor that this defendant was deprived of a substantial right or substantial procedure of right.

Michel v. Louisiana.speaker: Justice Burton
Michel v. Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 2: PORET V. LOUISIANA (36) - NOVEMBER 09, 1955

context.speaker: Harold Burton
context.text: -- that the man never could be tried, but in this case, you could be re-indicted.

context.speaker: Adrian G. Duplantier
context.text: What's that, sir?

context.speaker: Adrian G. Duplantier
context.text: I didn't get you.

context.speaker: Harold Burton
context.text: I say any case which you've just recited to Justice Black, man never could be into tried.

context.speaker: Harold Burton
context.text: But in -- in the case we have here, the man could be re-indicted.

context.speaker: Adrian G. Duplantier
context.text: Yes, he could.

Michel v. Louisiana.speaker: Justice Warren
Michel v. Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 2: PORET V. LOUISIANA (36) - NOVEMBER 09, 1955

context.speaker: Adrian G. Duplantier
context.text: Because the State may not have available information and it's likely that it won't, which it would have had available, had he not fled and had the theory provided 202 run against them.

context.speaker: Adrian G. Duplantier
context.text: That's what I say.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I get that.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But I get back to the question that Justice Black who asked you.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Do you know of any statute in any State that deprives a -- an accused person of any rights he may have on his trial or the procedure leading up to it because he is a fugitive from justice?

context.speaker: Adrian G. Duplantier
context.text: I -- I suggest that 202 doesn't.

Michel v. Louisiana.speaker: Justice Warren
Michel v. Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 2: PORET V. LOUISIANA (36) - NOVEMBER 09, 1955

context.speaker: Adrian G. Duplantier
context.text: Now, well that's the -- that's the point I wish to get over.

context.speaker: Adrian G. Duplantier
context.text: And with that Your Honors, I wish to submit remand.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Schreiber, Justice Frankfurter had one question he wanted to ask you --
No, it is me, Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Oh, what -- I beg your pardon, Justice Harlan.

Michel v. Louisiana.speaker: Justice Warren
Michel v. Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 2: PORET V. LOUISIANA (36) - NOVEMBER 09, 1955

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Schreiber, Justice Frankfurter had one question he wanted to ask you --
No, it is me, Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Oh, what -- I beg your pardon, Justice Harlan.

I want to ask you whether at the time the demurrer proceeding was tried before judge heard you made the claim that you'd understood that the extension of the arraignment had operated to give you a -- an extension of the time to file your motion to quash.

context.speaker: Gerard H. Schreiber
context.text: (Voice Overlap) --

National Labor Relations Board v. Babcoc.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
National Labor Relations Board v. Babcoc.case_name: National Labor Relations Board v. Babcock & Wilcox Company
National Labor Relations Board v. Babcoc.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 26, 1956

context.speaker: Eugene B. Schwartz
context.text: No, you asked about seven.

context.speaker: Eugene B. Schwartz
context.text: Yes, they are now -- to Mr. Justice Reed.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You answered Justice Black (Inaudible) affirmatively or negatively is dismissed by the Board.

context.speaker: Eugene B. Schwartz
context.text: Seven were dismissed by the Board.

context.speaker: Eugene B. Schwartz
context.text: It is not before this Court.

National Labor Relations Board v. Coca-C.speaker: Justice Warren
National Labor Relations Board v. Coca-C.case_name: National Labor Relations Board v. Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Louisville, Inc.
National Labor Relations Board v. Coca-C.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 17, 1956 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Oh, that's the --

context.speaker: John K. Skaggs, Jr.
context.text: -- and the Board ruled the same way that they ruled here.

context.speaker: John K. Skaggs, Jr.
context.text: Thank you very much.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Findling, would you mind answering Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question and then I believe you have want to correct some figures you gave, you may do that briefly.

context.speaker: David P. Findling
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, thank you.

context.speaker: David P. Findling
context.text: Of course, we don't permit the unions to tell us what our officer test is going to be nor to determine who are the officers.

context.speaker: Sidney S. Alderman
context.text: That's the most interesting question, Mr. Justice Clark.

context.speaker: Sidney S. Alderman
context.text: As I see it, the controlling jurisdictional statutes cover this Court as well as the Court of Appeals and I don't say if you should declare that the Courts of Appeals of the United States are wholly without this character review for abuse of discretion, that you would leave yourself in the position of being also unable to make such a review.

context.speaker: Sidney S. Alderman
context.text: Now, I was somewhat tried it but I cannot say for the --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible) if I understood the purport of Justice Clark's question, did you understood the difference the way I do.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I got -- I understood his question here.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Assuming that the question presented in the petition of certiorari, do not raise a particular question as to my relief, that is a here and concentrate questions presented one and two -- they present one and two and not three with different purchase.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I got -- I understood his question here.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Assuming that the question presented in the petition of certiorari, do not raise a particular question as to my relief, that is a here and concentrate questions presented one and two -- they present one and two and not three with different purchase.

context.speaker: Sidney S. Alderman
context.text: Thats right.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But as I understand the purport of Justice Clark's question assuming that that is so made this Court of its own motion note an obvious error in the judgment of the Court of Appeals which is tasked to review and which was sell the goods sustained on the issues amended but which also has an -- an (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Sidney S. Alderman
context.text: I understand sir -- I --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible) error --

context.speaker: Henry Hammer
context.text: There is no statutory limit.

context.speaker: Henry Hammer
context.text: There are not more or less than an undisputed amount.

context.speaker: Henry Hammer
context.text: They rest upon in absolute elements, questions which are matters to be determined and left to the --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well that would be to indicate what -- by Justice Burton.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That would be true in any case, and there's no power where it's difficult to fix money damage to consequences.

context.speaker: Henry Hammer
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: However, the changes in these orders have in fact been made as it's shown in the record.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: And they are somewhat plastic.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: It's unlike a statute which says, "This is it."

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I would assume that something like Justice Frankfurter has said originally here that if you have an order that tells the man where he can go, and what he must do, and where he cannot go, and he's hanging over it and as a -- generally, has supported family which purports to be under an Act of Congress and so forth, then as a justiciable controversy even though -- maybe it wouldn't be wise to (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: As far -- as far as any constitutional limits go, I absolutely agree with Your Honor.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: Whether it is the most efficient way to utilize the judicial process --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: We have used the less kindly but I believe accurate word of circumvention that --
You argue this on the premise, straightforward premise, that there was -- although there was an exercise of discretion here, this was an abusive discretion.
You don't stand on the proposition that there was a failure to exercise discretion.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: We do both, Mr. Justice Harlan.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It's a little difficult to know from what Judge Kennerly said, just exactly how it appeared to him.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: He said that in 24 years on the bench, I have never refused the -- a -- an effort on the part of the United States Attorney to dismiss the case.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Let us assume that Justice -- that Judge Kennerly had made it perfectly clear that he was exercising his discretion.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Let's assume that.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: If he had exercised his discretion to permit dismissal on the facts of this case, it would be our position that that was error.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Therefore, the answer to -- to your answer, if I may so, to Justice Harlan's question is that under those circumstances, could he have exercised the discretion in the way which you did and therefore, they should give direction to him to undo what he did.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: That is our position, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Yes --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: -- that's our position.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: -- and that is based on 21 (c)?

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It's based on 21 (a) and (c).

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And we rely heavily on 21 (c), Mr. Justice Reed.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: (c) -- (c) is what keeps it in this new district, is it?

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Everett L. Looney
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That was before then.

context.speaker: Everett L. Looney
context.text: It was filed with -- by the district attorney with his motion to dismiss, believed to dismiss, and wtih his statement of reasons for desiring to dismiss.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What you've asked -- that's what you had in mind, I take it in answering Justice Harlan's question that the cards were all on the table.

context.speaker: Everett L. Looney
context.text: They were all there, yes, sir.

context.speaker: Everett L. Looney
context.text: Now -- now, if Your Honors please, I -- there's some 70 odd cases.

context.speaker: Charles F. Barber
context.text: -- the fact of the last 15 years.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I should like to put this to you --

context.speaker: Charles F. Barber
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- and, infer this that the trouble entirely.Mr. Justice Harlan brought us back a minute ago to the -- to the question of this case.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Namely, we have a statute of Congress.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: We have state laws and the question is, whether statute of Congress has displaced them?

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: You mean with the prosecution during the State's power (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Charles F. Barber
context.text: No, but if a person in Pennsylvania, in downtown Pittsburg, made a speech inciting treason against the United States and there was a unrest and an outbreak of -- of riot was imminent, I think the States would have the power, the State in exercise of their -- or the police power to move in and stop the treasonable utterances.

context.speaker: Charles F. Barber
context.text: I -- I appreciate there is an overt act in the specific definition of treason that may distinguish the cases.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well suppose the State -- I -- I don't quite see why he's so -- from your point of view, why he is so convincingly felt they'd basically say no to Mr. Justice Douglas' question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Assume the State treason statute is in terms the basis of the characterization of it in the Federal Constitution, assume the same requirement as to quantum of proof, et cetera.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Why do -- I assume you --

Railway Employees' Department, American.speaker: Justice Warren
Railway Employees' Department, American.case_name: Railway Employees' Department, American Federation of Labor v. Hanson
Railway Employees' Department, American.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MAY 02, 1956 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Edson Smith
context.text: They're not lawful in any of the 18 States having right to work at.

context.speaker: Edson Smith
context.text: But, the Railway Labor Act, because it went farther and affirmatively authorized these contracts and attempted to sweep away the state law, and thereby, preempted the field if it's a constitutional statute, I say that is governmental action.

context.speaker: Edson Smith
context.text: Now, there's another aspect to this thing which will come before the Court.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I think -- I think your time has expired unless you're answering Mr. Justice Reed's question.

context.speaker: Edson Smith
context.text: Well, I thought --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: (Voice Overlap)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It can't be just to inquire whether without that particular functionary, the Pennsylvania couldn't conduct their business.

context.speaker: Joseph S. Lord, III
context.text: Precisely, sir, and that is the test which I am suggesting here, what I might call for one of a better word the withdrawal test.

context.speaker: Joseph S. Lord, III
context.text: Withdraw the duties performed by this particular individual and does interstate commerce suffer, is it affected or is it not?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I don't see why you difficulty in answering Justice Harlan's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I can't imagine that the President of Pennsylvania could carry on without having a secretary.

context.speaker: Joseph S. Lord, III
context.text: Well, perhaps, again like Senator Austin, it's an over abundance of caution, I didn't want to go too far and was trying to confine myself to the facts that we have here in the Reed case because I think in this case there is no question.

Riverbank Laboratories v. Hardwood Produ.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Riverbank Laboratories v. Hardwood Produ.case_name: Riverbank Laboratories v. Hardwood Products Corp.
Riverbank Laboratories v. Hardwood Produ.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 16, 1956 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Rosenfield, I -- I sent for Bull against Boston & Maine but until I get a chance to read it myself.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Would you tell me the part where that case play in your argument because in Canvas Fabricators case to which the Court of Appeals merely affirmed has having disposed of these questions.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: They rely mainly on Bull against Boston & Maine.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, the Bull against Boston & Maine do what Mr. Justice Burton has suggested, namely, although it didn't have to, a State is limited by the Due Process Clause but it may have a narrower line towards them, then the due process draw the line --

context.speaker: Maurice Rosenfield
context.text: Do you mean --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- but it can't – a State can't allow the suit where a person isn't amenable to judicial process according to due process law.

Slochower v. Board of Higher Education o.speaker: Justice Warren
Slochower v. Board of Higher Education o.case_name: Slochower v. Board of Higher Education of New York City
Slochower v. Board of Higher Education o.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 19, 1955

context.speaker: Ephraim London
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Ephraim London
context.text: They make no reference to Section 903.

context.speaker: Ephraim London
context.text: At least they didn't at the time this -- this case came up.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. London -- Mr. London, concerning the point you are making when Justice Frankfurter asked you his question and apropos his question I -- I just like to ask you, do you claim that this man has been denied the equal protection of the laws or that he's been denied due process or both?

context.speaker: Ephraim London
context.text: I claim that he -- that he has had a privilege abridged in violation --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: What --

Slochower v. Board of Higher Education o.speaker: Justice Burton
Slochower v. Board of Higher Education o.case_name: Slochower v. Board of Higher Education of New York City
Slochower v. Board of Higher Education o.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 19, 1955

context.speaker: Ephraim London
context.text: This same argument if made in a criminal prosecution would destroy the defense.
You -- you understand that the States says that that's evidence of the crime?

context.speaker: Ephraim London
context.text: I think I used their language that it would tend to show --

context.speaker: Harold Burton
context.text: What was your answer to Justice Harlan's (Inaudible)?

context.speaker: Ephraim London
context.text: Well, if it would tend to show it, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Ephraim London
context.text: If that's the inference to be drawn.

context.speaker: Arthur B. Dunne
context.text: Secondly, we don't have to guess as to whether Congress was aware of the course of decision in this Court as to the meaning of interstate commerce because the hearings and the report show that Congress was familiar at least with the Shanks case.

context.speaker: Arthur B. Dunne
context.text: And indeed in the Overstreet case, under the Fair Labor Standards Act, this Court commented on the fact that Congress was aware of the test to the Shanks case.

context.speaker: Arthur B. Dunne
context.text: We have then and this Court again has commented on this fairly recently in the Desper case which was an action under the Jones Act that the only thing that Congress did was redefine employees for the purposes of this Act.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I -- may I trouble you, Mr. Dunne, I'd like to -- the phrase that Mr. Justice Douglas called attention, “furtherance of interstate or foreign commerce”, was that in the proposed amendment of Section 1 at the time that the report in 6 (1) was committed to the (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Arthur B. Dunne
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That report was through a bill which has that phrase?

Sugden et ux. v. United States.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
Sugden et ux. v. United States.case_name: Sugden et ux. v. United States
Sugden et ux. v. United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 25, 1956 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Mark Wilmer
context.text: No one would have -- to have any authority from Congress to do that.

context.speaker: Mark Wilmer
context.text: No one has to have any authority to listen in.

context.speaker: Mark Wilmer
context.text: The sole prohibition is against divulgence and I assume that when the Congress drew the statute, they do it thoughtfully and carefully and I assume it employed words for a specific purpose and have a specific meaning so that for the purpose of monitoring and I assume that it is for the sole purpose of testing frequencies and of testing power and of ascertaining if there are unlicensed stations because the Congress specifically forbad to the Commission the authority to censor, specifically spelled out that nothing in the act should be construed to give the Commission the authority to censor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I go back to Justice Minton's question in your answer?

context.speaker: Mark Wilmer
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Section 605 said, "To have no person not being authorized by (Inaudible) shall intercept any communication (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Eugene T. Edwards
context.text: And for that reason, as it's shown by the letter of governor in view for gesture in the record, Texas vigorously protested, unless, there was a qualification to this authorization whereby New Mexico -- whereby, the -- the operation of the New Mexico facilities would be limited to a compliance with the Rio Grande -- with the Rio Grande Compact.

context.speaker: Eugene T. Edwards
context.text: And in pursuance of that objection and protest that was made by the State of Texas, the Congress of the United States when they authorized this arrangement with the Middle Rio Grande Conservancy District put in the Act that it was conditioned on the operation of the project facilities of the Middle Rio Grande Project being in conformity with the Rio Grande Compact as administered by the Rio Grande Compact Commission.

context.speaker: Eugene T. Edwards
context.text: So, under that Act of Congress, the United States nor the Bureau of Reclamation, nor any of these officers or agents can open a gate, can turn a wheel, or can operate a valve, unless it be in conformity with the Rio Grande Compact.

context.speaker: Harold Burton
context.text: Well, is that your answer to Justice Harlan's question that the United States was now in a position to interfere with any decree that is made here?

context.speaker: Eugene T. Edwards
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Eugene T. Edwards
context.text: That's -- that's -- I think a full answer, because the -- the right of the United States to possession or to operation, or to do anything else is conditional upon its compliance with the Rio Grande Compact as administered by the Rio Grande Compact Commission, and that's in -- that's in our brief, that's -- that's cited, the -- the --

United Automobile, Aircraft & Agricultur.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
United Automobile, Aircraft & Agricultur.case_name: United Automobile, Aircraft & Agricultural Implement Workers of America v. Wisconsin Employment Relations Board
United Automobile, Aircraft & Agricultur.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 25, 1956

context.speaker: Sherman Minton
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Jerome Powell
context.text: No, Your Honor, we don't contend that.

context.speaker: Jerome Powell
context.text: Although, Wisconsin's regulation, of course, can only apply intrastate but we say that Wisconsin in the exercise of its powers which Congress we believe has not displaced, has power to preserve the peace here.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, I'm not sure -- I'm not sure I follow you and your statement doesn't fall in Justice Minton's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If the Board found that this was lawful conduct, then why isn't that a collective activity protected by Section 7?

context.speaker: Jerome Powell
context.text: Because Wisconsin's regulation has not interfered with the -- with any activity which is protected.

United Mine Workers of America v. Arkans.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
United Mine Workers of America v. Arkans.case_name: United Mine Workers of America v. Arkansas Oak Floorings Company
United Mine Workers of America v. Arkans.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 23, 1956 (PART 2)

context.speaker: John L. Pitts
context.text: I don't know that I understand Your Honor's question.

context.speaker: John L. Pitts
context.text: I -- I'd say this that there is no question involved in this case of any employee discrimination if that's what the question is leading to.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: No, but that's -- if I may intervene.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Justice Minton, I haven't looked that long, I'm taking your word for it, I have a way of taking the words of lawyers in case it stands for something and sometimes it's disappointing.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I take your word that the Board has ruled that although a non-confirming union can't go before it and compel election that is also true of an employer no matter how much good faith he had, he can't go before the Board, so will it be holding an election to see the majority, is that right?

context.speaker: John L. Pitts
context.text: Yes, sir.

United States v. Contract Steel Carriers.speaker: Justice Douglas
United States v. Contract Steel Carriers.case_name: United States v. Contract Steel Carriers, Inc.
United States v. Contract Steel Carriers.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 29, 1956 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Robert N. Burchmore
context.text: Well, what exist in the minds of counsel might be different from what comes out of the advocate, [Laughs].

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well now, what have you most derived?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I assume that you (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: (Voice Overlap) Justice Harlan's question.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I think I meant to answer the question by saying that even if there were evidence here that -- that they had been at one time in operation as a common carrier, you would have to affirm the court below because the Commission did not decide the case upon that basis.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: The Commission explicitly waived the evidence in favor of deciding the case on the basis of its theory of contract carrier.

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: And this opinion starts out by saying he denies the motion for judgment -- acquittal.

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: And the order of the Court says, he denies it twice.

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: So --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What about the fore part of the sentence which Justice Black read.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Its -- Judge Moore in Saint Louis where the -- and could this -- and the jury couldn't have talked about this community?

context.speaker: Oscar H. Davis
context.text: No.

United States v. Minker.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
United States v. Minker.title: ORAL ARGUMENT, PART 1: FALCONE V. BARNES - NOVEMBER 14, 1955 (47)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But he stated specifically in connection with possibilities and to -- would you mind telling us.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I mean is --

context.speaker: George Morris Fay
context.text: It --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- Justice Reed right about it, as in questions whether --

context.speaker: George Morris Fay
context.text: It is conceivable that this statute --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All right.(Voice Overlap) --

United States v. Storer Broadcasting Com.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
United States v. Storer Broadcasting Com.case_name: United States v. Storer Broadcasting Company
United States v. Storer Broadcasting Com.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 29, 1956

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And therefore, he says, this isn't the public interest although you may have the general policy against more than five.

context.speaker: Warren E. Baker
context.text: That is an implied tender but certainly it needs more than an implied tender that this isn't the public interest to raise questions where you have adopted a rule which says, “This is not in the public interest.”

context.speaker: Warren E. Baker
context.text: If this is a valid exercise of the legislative, the quasi legislative rule making power, a policy determination that we should not permit more than five except on unusual circumstances, certainly, someone is required to allege those unusual circumstances to justify the Commission waiving the rules.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Another clearer way to (Inaudible) Justice Black then, your position then is that the restriction complied here as though Congress had written it into the statute.

context.speaker: Warren E. Baker
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Warren E. Baker
context.text: Except for the fact that it is because we have also the waiver provision, it is if Congress had written it in into the statute with the provision that in appropriate circumstances we could waive it.

United States v. Twin City Power Company.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
United States v. Twin City Power Company.case_name: United States v. Twin City Power Company
United States v. Twin City Power Company.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 18, 1955

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: They'd have to pay this extra price.

context.speaker: Ralph S. Spritzer
context.text: Well, assuming that there were -- that two persons, the buyer and the seller, were both free to make the use and then one got condemnation powers, it's certainly so.

context.speaker: Ralph S. Spritzer
context.text: But, our whole point is premised on the fact that neither Twin City nor anyone else was entitled to throw a dam across the river which was the necessary preliminary to appropriating the energy which, in here, is in the flow of the stream.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I get your answer to Justice Reed's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If a private company condemned this site, what is your -- what is your answer to Justice Reed's question --

United States v. Twin City Power Company.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
United States v. Twin City Power Company.case_name: United States v. Twin City Power Company
United States v. Twin City Power Company.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 18, 1955

context.speaker: Ralph S. Spritzer
context.text: Well, assuming that there were -- that two persons, the buyer and the seller, were both free to make the use and then one got condemnation powers, it's certainly so.

context.speaker: Ralph S. Spritzer
context.text: But, our whole point is premised on the fact that neither Twin City nor anyone else was entitled to throw a dam across the river which was the necessary preliminary to appropriating the energy which, in here, is in the flow of the stream.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I get your answer to Justice Reed's question.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If a private company condemned this site, what is your -- what is your answer to Justice Reed's question --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- as to the -- as to the value that may be attributed to this site for developing water or surfacing water power as a private concern even though, at the time, it may not have a license of the power but the land is concededly serving for that purpose.

context.speaker: Orrin G. Judd
context.text: We brought an omnibus motion for dismissal for vagueness, a dismissal for lack of an affidavit and for particulars.

context.speaker: Orrin G. Judd
context.text: The judge did not deny our motion for particulars.

context.speaker: Orrin G. Judd
context.text: He held that in advance because if the motion -- if the complaint was dismissed, there was no need to decide it and if the Government had filed the affidavit it might have supplied the particulars and he might not had decided that motion.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: As I understood your answer to Mr. Justice Clark it was that the affidavit might be made by any one that was familiar with the facts.

context.speaker: Orrin G. Judd
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: That would need to be filed with the -- of what's not -- not -- but either of facts from the examinations such as the Immigration Service as to the individual who had seen in, for instance, in the Communist Party.

context.speaker: Orrin G. Judd
context.text: But that's --

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Orrin G. Judd
context.text: Now, I'd like to touch briefly the question of judicial and administrative construction of this statute because that is always persuasive.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Before -- I'd like to continue Justice Clark's question just for a moment.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: The statute says, affidavit of good cause, doesn't it?

context.speaker: Orrin G. Judd
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That would be based on specific circumstances of a particular affidavit.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: I'm still unclear about your position.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: Must -- must the affidavit be by a person who is familiar with the fact itself so to be competent in evidence in the Court to sustain the complaint or can it be made on information and belief?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well maybe the reason I haven't made myself clear is because I haven't given great asperity to the form of the affidavit, the necessity of the affidavit is what I'm primarily concerned Mr. Justice Reed.

context.speaker: Stanley Reed
context.text: This isn't -- not a question of form, this is a question of who furnishes the affidavit.

context.speaker: Orrin G. Judd
context.text: I think -- I think there are some things in the affidavit which may definitely be on information and belief.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Robert F. Peckham
context.text: It was not -- it was -- it does not appear -- it's not in the record Your Honor, no.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Your answer to Justice Clark, he admits the reach of this evidence but never objected on the ground that it's in violation of due process of law.

context.speaker: Robert F. Peckham
context.text: It doesn't appear in the record, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Voice Overlap) that would be in the record.

context.speaker: Clarence A. Linn
context.text: It went back and the California court took -- took quite a little time in coming to it, you've got to ask them twice.

context.speaker: Clarence A. Linn
context.text: And finally, they -- they rendered the decision and they based it upon a couple of adequate state grounds as I properly would.

context.speaker: Clarence A. Linn
context.text: That procedure is possible, but here, I don't think you could get that far because, first, you got to get over the hurdle of self-incrimination.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible) Justice Clark why the judgment read -- why we don't know on what ground it's referenced.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I don't know the purpose (Inaudible) jurisdiction, if you ask (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: We don't know whether they based it on state ground or in federal ground (Inaudible) state ground, in federal ground and not in the factual ground.

context.speaker: Morton H. Hollander
context.text: There was an appeal to the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Morton H. Hollander
context.text: It was resolved again by the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Morton H. Hollander
context.text: Both courts --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Hollander, I don't -- I don't believe you carried through to a conclusion your answer to Mr. Justice Black on whether this situation is controlled by federal or state law.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Would you -- would you give us a precise answer to that?

context.speaker: Morton H. Hollander
context.text: Our short answer, Your Honor, is that the matter is controlled by federal law.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: As pointed out to --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: -- Mr. Justice --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I thought your answer to Mr. Justice Frankfurter was that that's exactly what you claimed that it was a discretionary matter with this Court whether we would take it or not.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: Only if the Court has jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: I failed to make myself clear about that.
